Different Crime.Crime Name: Misrepresentation under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

decision_outcome: appeal referred back to RAD for reconsideration
standard_of_review: RAD must conduct its own analysis

relevant_rule: RAD must review evidence presented to the RPD
discretion_exercise: RAD should have reviewed all evidence

procedural_fairness: no fair opportunity to present case

decision_reasoning: RAD's incorrect application of reasonableness standard
procedure_followed: court analyzed RAD's application of reasonableness standard under IRPA
result_of_case: RAD must reassess claim using hybrid appeal approach

legal_basis: sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

procedural_fairness: procedural unfairness due to probation status

application_details: Sahota was on probation during his citizenship hearing and requested an adjournment until after his probation ended
decision_reasoning: probation status legally barred him from citizenship
cause_of_action: Sahota's multiple criminal convictions led to probation
procedure_followed: Sahota appealed the denial of his citizenship application
Federal Court reviewed the case based on conflicting accounts of the hearing
result_of_case: Sahota remained ineligible for citizenship due to ongoing probation

judicial_review_process: Federal Court assessment of RAD's decision-making process

decision_reasoning: no other reasonable way to bring the issue to court

legal_basis: Veterans Review and Appeal Board Act
evidence_assessment: corroborating evidence from a witness and medical reports
decision_reasoning: failed to provide reasons for rejecting evidence
application_details: Veteran's claim for pension benefits denied
conclusion_outcome: application for judicial review is allowed
relevant_statute: s. 39 of the Veterans Review and Appeal Board Act
discretion_exercise: doubted the applicant's claim despite corroborating evidence
evidentiary_standard: new, credible, and uncontradicted evidence favorably considered

decision_reasoning: H&C analysis inadequately addressed BIOC factors
relevant_statute: PRRA requires proving more than a mere possibility of persecution
H&C analysis must consider BIOC comprehensively
application_details: Applicant challenged CIC decisions regarding her PRRA and H&C applications
procedure_followed: Judicial review analyzed legal tests and evidence sufficiency in both applications

legal_basis: Rule 222 of the Federal Courts Rules
evidence_assessment: documents a party intends to rely on
documents that adversely affect their case/support another's case
procedure_followed: Novopharm moved for an order requiring Lilly to produce further documents before oral discovery began
decision_reasoning: post-2001 documents relevant but rejected wholesale disclosure requests
result_of_case: Lilly ordered to produce specific additional documents
motion otherwise dismissed with costs in the cause
cause_of_action: Patent infringement claim by Lilly against Novopharm

decision_reasoning: CPMA's activities do not equate to government control or regulatory power
application_details: CPMA sought to register 'PODIATRIST' as an official mark
procedure_followed: Judicial review application by College of Chiropodists challenging Registrar's approval of CPMA's mark
result_of_case: CPMA's official mark invalidated due to lack of public authority status

decision_reasoning: insufficient evidence to dismiss the political nexus
application_details: Shahiraj claimed refugee status in Canada
procedural_fairness: judicial review of the Board's decision
certification of the legal question regarding mixed motives
conclusion_outcome: Federal Court quashed the Board's decision

humanitarian_and_compassionate_factors: application denied based partly on undisclosed evidence

procedural_fairness: notifying applicants of evidence used against them
humanitarian_compassionate_consideration: humanitarian & compassionate grounds for permanent residence
decision_outcome: ordered reconsideration by a different officer

Different Crime.Crime Name: Failure to Disclose Material Information under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
misrepresentation_or_fraud: inducing error in administration of the Act
legal_basis: paragraph 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

judicial_review_process: Judicial review of the Commission’s decision
burden_of_proof: complaint must be filed within one year of the alleged discriminatory act unless the Commission extends this period

Different Crime.Crime Name: Breach of natural justice in immigration proceedings
procedural_fairness: continuous, precise, competent, impartial, and contemporaneous interpretation
judicial_review_process: review of IAD's refusal to reopen case based on alleged interpretation issues
administrative_error: alleged interpretation errors deemed trivial by IAD
reasonableness_of_decision: court agreed with IAD's finding of no material impact on fairness
decision_outcome: no breach of natural justice; judicial review dismissed
burden_of_proof: no requirement to show actual prejudice for breach

procedural_fairness: continuous, precise, competent, impartial, and contemporaneous interpretation
appeal_process: IAD's refusal to reopen the appeal

application_details: details about a Canadian soldier's offense
evidence_assessment: personal details (e.g., service number, mental state) were withheld
decision_reasoning: these details fit the definition of 'personal information' under s. 3 of the Privacy Act and did not meet any exemptions
conclusion_outcome: application for judicial review was dismissed
result_of_case: upheld the decision to withhold certain personal information

Different Crime.Crime Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act due to organized criminality
evidence_provided: engaging in murder, extortion, and assault

applicant_involvement: reasonable grounds to believe the applicant was a member
reasonableness_of_decision: decision was reasonable and supported by evidence

Different Crime.Crime Name: Reasonable grounds to believe in involvement in indictable offences outside Canada
involvement_details: engaged in murder, extortion, and assault
reasonableness_of_decision: reasonable given the nature of the crimes
judicial_review_result: court certified a question for appeal regarding equivalency analysis and dual criminality
complicity_in_crimes: alleged membership in a criminal organization in Macau

patent_validity: Syntex's patents properly claim the medicine itself or its use
relevant_rule: Patented Medicines (Notice of Compliance) Regulations define 'claim for the medicine itself' and 'medicine'
application_of_law: Only claims for the medicine itself or its use are protected
dispute_focus: whether Syntex's patents qualify for protection under the Regulations
procedure_followed: Judicial review of patent claims and interpretation of regulatory language
court_ruling: Court rules in favor of Syntex, prohibiting NOC issuance until patent expiration

refugee_status_eligibility: claimed refugee status due to persecution

legal_basis: section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

decision_reasoning: balancing its gatekeeping role with the need for investigation
lack of evidence or jurisdictional issues
standard_of_review: substantial deference unless legal errors are evident
application_details: PSAC's complaint against NAV, WHA, and other agencies as individual respondents
allegations against some agencies as co-respondents with TB
result_of_case: significant aspects of the complaint proceed to investigation while others were reasonably excluded
discretion_exercise: decline dealing with complaints if they appear beyond jurisdiction or lack reasonable grounds

procedural_fairness: Designated Member's decision to grant leave procedurally fair and legally valid
applicable_regulations: Canada Pension Plan and PAB Rules
application_details: Respondent's application lacked required details per Rule 4
decision_reasoning: no reasons were given for granting leave, making it impossible to assess legal correctness
result_of_case: judicial review application is allowed; the leave-granting decision is quashed and remitted for re-determination
procedure_followed: Judicial review analyzed procedural fairness, necessity of reasons, and compliance with rules in granting leave

procedural_fairness: failure to provide opportunity to respond
failure to resolve the issue promptly

risk_of_persecution: lack of persecution based on race or fundamental rights
nexus_to_convention_grounds: property rights claims are not grounds for refugee protection
procedural_fairness: judicial review in Federal Court with arguments from both applicant and respondent

risk_assessment: potential harm if deported to Ghana found speculative

legal_basis: Section 18.1 of the Federal Court Act
Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act s. 5, 22(1)
decision_reasoning: Rule 1602 does not allow class actions or general orders
application_details: Applicants claim RCMP improperly refuses meal allowances

decision_reasoning: retaliation complaint better addressed under another act

specific_rule_applied: Rule 221(1)(a) of the Federal Courts Rules
procedure_followed: Appeal from Prothonotary's order striking out parts of the statement of claim
decision_reasoning: distinguishing cases supports allowing the action to proceed
result_of_case: appeal granted with costs to plaintiffs
court_ruling: Judicial review is not required before pursuing damages

legal_basis: sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
decision_reasoning: adequate state protection available in Mexico
cause_of_action: fearing retaliation from a drug trafficker after refusing involvement in criminal activities
procedure_followed: judicial review application filed challenging RPD's rejection of refugee claims based on sections 96 and 97
result_of_case: Federal Court upheld RPD's decision, dismissing the application for judicial review
risk_of_persecution: refusal to participate in drug trafficking
state_protection: adequate state protection available in Mexico
standard_of_review: reasonable and within the range of acceptable outcomes
decision_made: dismissed the application for judicial review
evidence_presented: Applicants claimed persecution due to refusal to participate in drug trafficking

procedural_fairness: principles of fairness and jurisdictional limits
decision_outcome: judicial review application dismissed as premature

decision_reasoning: committee hasn’t ruled on its jurisdiction or privilege issues
cause_of_action: allegations about a judge's past conduct as a lawyer
procedure_followed: court analyzed whether the judicial review was timely and if the Inquiry Committee had proper jurisdiction under the Judges Act
result_of_case: motion to strike the judicial review was granted
